‚≠ê Dave the Diver ~ 10/10 After 6 Hours of Pure Joy

After just six hours in Dave the Diver, I am absolutely hooked. This game is the perfect blend of chill exploration, goofy charm, and unexpectedly deep management gameplay. One moment I‚Äôm diving through the Blue Hole hunting for rare fish, soaking in the gorgeous pixel art and dreamy soundtrack and the next I‚Äôm sprinting around my sushi restaurant, serving customers, upgrading gear, and obsessing over the next menu idea like a proud little ocean chef.

The pacing is incredibly addictive. Every dive feels rewarding, every upgrade feels meaningful, and every new character adds charm and personality to the world. The writing is quirky in the best way, and the game constantly surprises with how much variety it packs into each session. It‚Äôs the kind of experience where you say ‚Äújust one more dive‚Äù and suddenly an hour has vanished.

For my first six hours, I‚Äôve been smiling nonstop. Dave the Diver is cozy, adventurous, funny, and full of heart. If the rest of the game keeps this energy, it‚Äôs easily one of my top indie experiences in years.

Final Verdict: 10/10 ~ Already obsessed, already recommending it to everyone. üå∏üê∫üå∏

Dave is a humble people pleasure who is constantly taken advantage of, made fun of and rarely achieves any recognition. He dives for fish at day and serves it at night because who needs sleep when you have profit??

He catches fish like he's trying to pay off every debt he's ever had and still somehow has the energy to serve sushi at night. He fights giant squids and jellyfish and he nearly dies every day but still shows up to work like nothing happened.

He doesn't eat and despite the excessive exercise he is still fat. But he is also strong fat and can carry half a ton on his back.

Dave is also the only person in the world who has defeated multiple great white sharks using weapons such as a rubber chicken, a tennis racket and a dead fish.

He is so broke he has to look for ingredients like olive oil, black vinegar, soy sauce, curry, mayonnaise and cat food in the depths of the ocean. I think he lives on the boat and there's this guy there who never ever leaves and who tries to sell him illicit stuff.

Dave is underpaid at work, abused by everyone and he never gets a break. He needs to go to HR but he is too nice for that. I just want Dave to be happy.

Not long after starting Dave the Diver it soon becomes clear that there's a lot more to this game than just calmly diving for fish.

In fact, it's surprising the variety of other activities you can do. From running a restaurant and elevating its popularity, growing produce for your restaurants, to creating and upgrading specific gear to improve your ability to catch more elusive underwater creatures and even defeat sea monsters.

I particularly like the creepy night dives, where the strange creatures that lurk in the depths can quickly have you scrambling to the surface before they ruin what would otherwise have been a good nights catch.

Whatever Dave is tasked to do, whether below the waves or not, you will find there is more than enough to keep you occupied here.

Dave the diver: A great game about diving into a shapeshifting ocean with all kinds of Fishes, experiences, zones and bosses.

From just diving into the ocean, gathering fishes, materials and sometimes even fighting bosses, while discovering more about the whole world it has hidden to managing a restaurant, doing different dishes, hiring people to work on the restaurant, sending them to gather spices, upgrading them and the restaurant, and having chef competitions as well! 
This game has everything it needs to be fun, relaxed, tense and never boring (as well as easter eggs from different games of diverse franchises)

negative.review: I understand a lot of the appeal for this game: the artwork is nice, every character is brimming with personality etc... but I have put 30 hours into this game and I am beyond frustrated with the gameplay loop. Or rather that the game wont leave me alone so that I can just play the fucking game. After every single single dive there will be a brand new thing to learn or person to meet or minigame shoved in your face that is not skippable. It has been 30 hours of non-stop tutorials. I just want to get fish and make sushi, and even more frustrating is that the new mechanics that are introduced I would actually like usually, but why for the love of fucking christ is something like the farm introduced but you are not allowed to use it at all until like ten real life hours later when otto finally decides its time for you to be able to buy seeds. I would genuinely enjoy 90% of the extra content if it just wasnt constantly shoved down my throat. Dave cant even move from room to room without another text box popping up, just for him to tell you "its dark in here". I thought for sure that at some point I could just play the game for a while, but for real, every five goddamn minutes the controls are taken away from the player and you are subjected to a thousand text boxes. Holy shit leave me alone for a while I was doing shit.

It's OK at first. There's some good stuff here but the fun ran out pretty rapidly for me. The normal game play loop is very repetitive but is the best part of the game. Once you get tired of that it's over. I hated all the mini games, they all felt like a chore.

Also based on the way the game was described I expected much more procedural generation of the dive maps. It's very much static with minor changes which quickly means the exploration element goes out the window. There are a few map variations but not much. I understand why this is but I was sad on my 2nd dive when it was the exact same map.

The controls seem to be decided at random and are not assignable. It makes me frustrated. 

The art style is a choice for sure. If you're into pixels you won't be disappointed. Not for me.

There's nothing strictly speaking wrong with this game. Every bit of it is competently put together. Why negative, then? Because it is ALL tedium. Even what little bits of assistance you get in reducing tedium are soon replaced by a farcical level of additional tedium, all the way into the fucking postgame!

[h1] What is this game? [/h1]
Dave the Diver is a roguelite collectathon with a focus on gathering ingredients for your sushi restaurant.
As you upgrade your equipment you'll be able to gather larger, and better, quality fish and plants.

[h2] Price/replay value [/h2]
Horrible - Bad - [u] Decent [/u] - Good - Amazing

[h2] Achievement hunting [/h2]
Only 1 missable (eat rations) - most involve grinding and will be post game if you rush the story.
The most tedious are definitely all bosses, diamond cooksta, and lvl 20 employee.

[h2] Pros/cons [/h2]
[b] Pros [/b]
[list]
[*]Amazing soundtrack (mxmtoon included)
[*]Very charming characters and artstyle
[*]Tons of freedom when it comes to restaurant customisation
[/list]

[b] Cons [/b]
[list]
[*]Mid-game has horrendous pacing
[*]Combat sucks
[*]Grinding used as padding
[/list]

[h2] Overall opinion [/h2]
Honestly, this game isn't "bad" per se. But I'm giving it a negative review regardless due to the glaring issues with it.
The early game (what most positive reviews are talking about) - was great. The game starts out with a ton of charm and would seem like a cult classic right out the gate. You explore, you dive, you defeat sharks... The issue starts to arise around chapter 3-5. As soon as you start doing the sea people related stuff you'll be forced into a multitude of escort missions, slowly grinding through fetch quests, and other various things that don't respect your time. If you look at the completion percentage, you'll clearly see how more than 20% of the active players stopped before reaching the glacial area (which just happens to be after these chapters)... Once you get past that point the game honestly becomes a lot more tolerable, but the damage will have been done by that point.

Story aside, this game holds your hand with an iron grip all the way until the post game. You'll be constantly forced into watching cutscene upon cutscene, answering calls from npcs, having to take on side quests you didn't agree to, and overall waiting to be able to play the damn game again. I can understand wanting to add a lot of worldbuilding, but the sheer amount of forced interaction really detracts from actually feeling like the main character. On top of that you'll have to watch unskippable cutscenes before bosses and certain sections, which can be a nuisance if you just want to retry something after death.

This game also isn't officially tagged as a collectathon, but it very much should be. Getting the steel net gun (required for the full gold marinica dex) - requires you to get [b] 20 topaz and 3 pelican eel skin. [/b] For those unfamiliar - you'll be able to get about 8-12 topaz from the glacial area if you get [i] every [/i] node. Pelican eel skin however is a rare drop from... you guessed it... Pelican eels. [i] There is exactly 1 pelican eel in the entire game [/i] - also being in an annoying to reach section of the map. This means you'll have to do (at least) 3 dives for this specific fish, just to make a weapon that's required to finish the marinica dex. This is assuming you get perfect rng... Same goes for some other weapons which require trevaly fins, shark teeth, tentacles... Though at least these have more than a single fish to grind. This just felt like such a padded upgrade that should not have required more than 1 skin imo.

My final complaint is the combat. This game has horrendous combat in basically every way, shape, and form. 
Sharks have an average of like 200~ ish health. Your max harpoon gun does 40. This means you'll be shooting most sharks 5-8 times to kill them (with aim that only goes in a cone of about 90 degrees horizontally) - against enemies who constantly try to dash at you with the hitbox of a train. Especially on the thresher shark this feels ridiculous, as that thing goes across the screen in 0.5 seconds upon entering its range. The fact dave moves at the speed of a sea slug (even with dash and sprint) really doesn't help this.
Note that all sharks also hit for about 40-80 oxygen (oxygen acts as health) when your max is about 320. Merely touching a shark counts as getting hit so you'll be losing about half your health if a shark is just turning around and happens to be inside your hitbox (this will happen almost every time as the harpoon range is non-existent). 
Now imagine trying to fight a boss with 500+ hp, and the same mechanics. On top of this you only get 1 heal in the entire arena, and basically need an upgraded weapon to not be hit every few seconds. This means your best bet is usually just taking a sniper rifle, upgrading it to max, and emptying your entire magazine before the boss can even move, just to kill them before they can kill you. Overall - extremely shoddy.

[h2] tldr; [/h2]
Charming, but horrendous combat and grind.

[h2] Should you buy it? [/h2]
Depending on what you can tolerate, maybe. The average gamer won't enjoy this enough to finish it however.

I don't really want to rate DTD negatively, as there's so much to like here: the art style, the initial gameplay loop, the characterisation, the comedic tone, the beautiful soundtrack. All of it makes the first half of the game a deeply enjoyable experience. However, simply put, the game evolves into a series of mini-games that simply aren't fun. There's not a lot of synergy between them and it pulls you consistently away from the central gameplay loop of catching fish and running the sushi restaurant. It's frustrating, for lack of a better word. I really loved much of the game, but there's no sense in the direction that it takes beyond having that initial sense of charm. It quickly becomes a slog and one that you won't feel compelled to see the end of. You end up fighting through un-fun sections of a game to get to the good bit: its central gameplay loop. But once that's taken away from you, it's basically impossible to get the spark back. A shame, there's a lot to like here (at least for the first act!).

Holy shit leave me alone for a while I was doing shit.

I initially enjoyed diving, exploring, and managing my restaurant, but I lost that enjoyment when the focus shifted to following a (very shallow and clich√©) storyline, completing (unchallenging, repetitive) quest objectives, exploring dungeons, solving puzzles etc. This is a very ambitious game with a good sense of humour, and it certainly has some good moments, but it is stretched too thin. Dave the Diver is a very well-made game with a very unique combination of gameplay elements, a great art style, and a positive laid-back vibe. Despite all this the game just wasn't for me, and I didn't enjoy it. Here's why:

A jack of all trades is a master of none. My main issue with Dave the Diver is that it just tries to do way too many things without ever focusing enough on one element. The first 5 hours were great; all I wanted to do was catch fish, run my sushi restaurant, and ignore the main plot. But as I progressed, they just kept introducing more and more and MORE. Oh here's a fish farm, oh here's a new location with 50 zillion fetch-quests, oh here's a farm, oh now you can dive at night, oh here's a camera to take pictures, oh by the way did you get all the ingredients for the 15th VIP guest we have tonight? Every core element of this game feels like it would have been so much better if they had focused more time and attention on those core gameplay elements rather than the dozens and dozens of smaller, less interesting elements. The game is so bloated that the extremely lackluster plot absolutely CRAWLS along. The most fun I had with this game was when it randomly turned into Balatro, but that's probably a sign that I just need to go buy Balatro. 

But that being said, it was still fun enough for me to willingly finish it (albeit begrudgingly). I think most people would actually have a blast with this game and it's very well-made. It just wasn't for me for the above reasons. If it looks like fun, I would say ignore my review and give it a shot because there's a lot to enjoy in this game and if it's your thing then this game would be a blast.

I'm going to start with the positives
The art style is incredible, there are quite a few funny cutscenes, Bancho is incredible.
The core loop of finding new fish, hiring staff, cooking new dishes is quite fun.
The idea behind most of the other mechanics is also fun

The issue is with how shallow everything is, how poor is the game feel.
18 hours in and there are still tutorials being presented, the game doesn't let you explore, everything is on tight rails.

It all feels very constricted, from movement speed (and the lack of upgrades to it) to only unlocking the ability to track ingredients at 12 hours in to the lack of QOL features like being able to sell low quality fish from the Fish Farm (Going 1 by 1 with 10+ fishes is mind numbing, and the actual UI being right stick to select an amount is... innovative)

Taking 5 minutes to swim from top to bottom every single time, where the map is barely randomised (6 weapons in 20 hours), where the layout is pretty much irrelevant (no secrets, little variation), does not feel fun.

As I said the "core" loop, of finding different fishes, upgrading your restaurant and hiring staff is quite fun.
Unfortunately the game does not want to emphasise it, it's fetch quest after fetch quest, cutscenes every 3 minutes...

The nail in the coffin to the restrictive nature of the game is how everything you do takes control from you, 5 seconds moving the camera to a point, 2 seconds to actually be able to fire, 2 seconds to skip a dialogue line.
It sounds very small but the game just... feels stiff, in every single interaction.

This feels like a shallow Stardew Valley in the ocean and it's really a shame because it could've been so much more.

Everything about this game is designed in such a way that makes it so inconvenient to do anything fun. Cutscenes aren't funny the first or the fifth time. You move too slow even for a "casual" game, and far too slow especially for mandatory boss fights that beat the abysmal pacing further into its grave. And holding down buttons to loot, to move to a different location, etc. is such an outdated mechanic that only exists to pad out the threadbare gameplay.

The puzzles make Pokemon gym puzzles look difficult, and five seconds can't pass without your protagonist commenting on exactly what glowing interactable they have to touch.  Your skill and success don't seem to advance the story meaningfully, and new mechanics seem to just be arbitrarily introduced on the calendar instead of upon surpassing any sort of milestone.  I've spent at least an hour walking from one end of an area to the other with no hindrances on the way for the classic 'walk from A to B and back' fetch quests.

The fishing mechanics are pretty fun, but once again the pressures of oxygen or damage aren't the most pressing; the limiting factor in your advancement today is largely your carry weight.  In short, just go play Subnautica again, and pick up a restaurant tycoon game on the side.

I just want to get fish and make sushi, and even more frustrating is that the new mechanics that are introduced I would actually like usually, but why for the love of fucking christ is something like the farm introduced but you are not allowed to use it at all until like ten real life hours later when otto finally decides its time for you to be able to buy seeds. I would genuinely enjoy 90% of the extra content if it just wasnt constantly shoved down my throat. Dave cant even move from room to room without another text box popping up, just for him to tell you "its dark in here". I thought for sure that at some point I could just play the game for a while, but for real, every five goddamn minutes the controls are taken away from the player and you are subjected to a thousand text boxes. Holy shit leave me alone for a while I was doing shit.

I don't really want to rate DTD negatively, as there's so much to like here: the art style, the initial gameplay loop, the characterisation, the comedic tone, the beautiful soundtrack. All of it makes the first half of the game a deeply enjoyable experience. However, simply put, the game evolves into a series of mini-games that simply aren't fun. There's not a lot of synergy between them and it pulls you consistently away from the central gameplay loop of catching fish and running the sushi restaurant. It's frustrating, for lack of a better word. I really loved much of the game, but there's no sense in the direction that it takes beyond having that initial sense of charm. It quickly becomes a slog and one that you won't feel compelled to see the end of. You end up fighting through un-fun sections of a game to get to the good bit: its central gameplay loop. But once that's taken away from you, it's basically impossible to get the spark back. A shame, there's a lot to like here (at least for the first act!).

Wide as an ocean but deep as a puddle. There are too many mechanics and not all of them are equally treated. The sea village is a slog to move around in. Fishing + restaurant loop is fun but the restaurant becomes pretty much irrelevant mid-game because most of the time you're diving.

I almost got to the end but I'm rage quitting because the death penalty of losing all your inventory but one is too harsh because of how long each dive takes near the end game. Random shark encounter that you can't outrun and you have to do dive for another 60 mins

This game can't decide what it wants to be. It is trying to do everything at the same time, and in the end, no part of the game really feels well-developed and worth recommending. I initially enjoyed diving, exploring, and managing my restaurant, but I lost that enjoyment when the focus shifted to following a (very shallow and clich√©) storyline, completing (unchallenging, repetitive) quest objectives, exploring dungeons, solving puzzles etc. This is a very ambitious game with a good sense of humour, and it certainly has some good moments, but it is stretched too thin. Everything Dave the Diver tries to do, another game has already done better.

Dave the Diver is a very well-made game with a very unique combination of gameplay elements, a great art style, and a positive laid-back vibe. Despite all this the game just wasn't for me, and I didn't enjoy it. Here's why:

A jack of all trades is a master of none. My main issue with Dave the Diver is that it just tries to do way too many things without ever focusing enough on one element. The first 5 hours were great; all I wanted to do was catch fish, run my sushi restaurant, and ignore the main plot. But as I progressed, they just kept introducing more and more and MORE. Oh here's a fish farm, oh here's a new location with 50 zillion fetch-quests, oh here's a farm, oh now you can dive at night, oh here's a camera to take pictures, oh by the way did you get all the ingredients for the 15th VIP guest we have tonight? Every core element of this game feels like it would have been so much better if they had focused more time and attention on those core gameplay elements rather than the dozens and dozens of smaller, less interesting elements. The game is so bloated that the extremely lackluster plot absolutely CRAWLS along. The most fun I had with this game was when it randomly turned into Balatro, but that's probably a sign that I just need to go buy Balatro. 

But that being said, it was still fun enough for me to willingly finish it (albeit begrudgingly). I think most people would actually have a blast with this game and it's very well-made. It just wasn't for me for the above reasons. If it looks like fun, I would say ignore my review and give it a shot because there's a lot to enjoy in this game and if it's your thing then this game would be a blast.

Starts off super strong. I really like the overall vibes of this game as well as the diving mechanics and sections. However the more you play the game the more it turns into "work" you'll have to side manage so many things that it starts getting tedious after a while I simply stopped enjoying the game from a certain point.

Maybe I'll pick it up again sometime in the future. If you're into farming/grinding games then I guess this could be for you, but for me this isn't it.

Also time gated dlc purchases are predatory shit.

There's nothing strictly speaking wrong with this game. Every bit of it is competently put together. Why negative, then? Because it is ALL tedium. Even what little bits of assistance you get in reducing tedium are soon replaced by a farcical level of additional tedium, all the way into the fucking postgame!

I am unsure whether to reccomend this game. I had a lot of fun, but the way the saving system works sucks a lot of fun out of it at times. I don't have the time for hours long gaming sessions that I feel held hostage to because I can't save. There are many fat jokes that seem meanspirited after the umpteenth time. I love the sushi minigame and all the species of fish, but I rarely get to play the restaurant part sicne I take so long in the sea.

I really wanted to like this game, but there's so much that just stops you from actual playing.

I'm going to start with the positives
The art style is incredible, there are quite a few funny cutscenes, Bancho is incredible.
The core loop of finding new fish, hiring staff, cooking new dishes is quite fun.
The idea behind most of the other mechanics is also fun

The issue is with how shallow everything is, how poor is the game feel.
18 hours in and there are still tutorials being presented, the game doesn't let you explore, everything is on tight rails.

It all feels very constricted, from movement speed (and the lack of upgrades to it) to only unlocking the ability to track ingredients at 12 hours in to the lack of QOL features like being able to sell low quality fish from the Fish Farm (Going 1 by 1 with 10+ fishes is mind numbing, and the actual UI being right stick to select an amount is... innovative)

Taking 5 minutes to swim from top to bottom every single time, where the map is barely randomised (6 weapons in 20 hours), where the layout is pretty much irrelevant (no secrets, little variation), does not feel fun.

As I said the "core" loop, of finding different fishes, upgrading your restaurant and hiring staff is quite fun.
Unfortunately the game does not want to emphasise it, it's fetch quest after fetch quest, cutscenes every 3 minutes...

The nail in the coffin to the restrictive nature of the game is how everything you do takes control from you, 5 seconds moving the camera to a point, 2 seconds to actually be able to fire, 2 seconds to skip a dialogue line.
It sounds very small but the game just... feels stiff, in every single interaction.

This feels like a shallow Stardew Valley in the ocean and it's really a shame because it could've been so much more.

It's OK at first. There's some good stuff here but the fun ran out pretty rapidly for me. The normal game play loop is very repetitive but is the best part of the game. Once you get tired of that it's over. I hated all the mini games, they all felt like a chore.

Also based on the way the game was described I expected much more procedural generation of the dive maps. It's very much static with minor changes which quickly means the exploration element goes out the window. There are a few map variations but not much. I understand why this is but I was sad on my 2nd dive when it was the exact same map.

The controls seem to be decided at random and are not assignable. It makes me frustrated. 

The art style is a choice for sure. If you're into pixels you won't be disappointed. Not for me.

Really fun and addicting game until the mermaid section, after that its really hard to want to play again. I want to give a thumbs up because it was fun, but the fact that nothing will ever draw me back to the game makes it a thumbs down.
Very overrated IMO. The beginning of the game is very fun but as you progress it becomes more like Dave the Farming Sim.
extremely overrated, gameplay loops gets old fast and then game just throws dozen of minigames to keep you interested.

Serious Issue:
The bosses in this game have no clear patterns and have way too much HP. They always seem to know exactly when the player is refilling oxygen and rush in at that moment ‚Äî while the refill process forces the character to stand still and do absolutely nothing. This makes the fights feel unfair and frustrating rather than challenging.

Everything about this game is designed in such a way that makes it so inconvenient to do anything fun. Cutscenes aren't funny the first or the fifth time. You move too slow even for a "casual" game, and far too slow especially for mandatory boss fights that beat the abysmal pacing further into its grave. And holding down buttons to loot, to move to a different location, etc. is such an outdated mechanic that only exists to pad out the threadbare gameplay.

It's a fun concept, but I've never played a game with more padding and handholding.  The puzzles make Pokemon gym puzzles look difficult, and five seconds can't pass without your protagonist commenting on exactly what glowing interactable they have to touch.  Your skill and success don't seem to advance the story meaningfully, and new mechanics seem to just be arbitrarily introduced on the calendar instead of upon surpassing any sort of milestone.  I've spent at least an hour walking from one end of an area to the other with no hindrances on the way for the classic 'walk from A to B and back' fetch quests.

The fishing mechanics are pretty fun, but once again the pressures of oxygen or damage aren't the most pressing; the limiting factor in your advancement today is largely your carry weight.  In short, just go play Subnautica again, and pick up a restaurant tycoon game on the side.

Not thrilling enough to be that repetitive for more than 8 hours. The gameplay loop is super simple, not bad per se, just very simple. This is the type of game I'd have loved when I was 14 and addicted to Lemonade Tycoon on my first gen iPod touch.
